title: So I just realized the main difference between League and Dota
body:
the former is an Action game that is slowly removing all Strategy and the latter is a Strategy game that is slowly removing all Action


League vs DotA 
Unreliability vs Reliability 
Mechanics vs Knowledge 
Action vs Timing and Precision 
Dynamic and Unpredictable vs Stable and Rigid 
How to kill the dude vs When to kill the dude

You can see this in the item system. League gives you items to promote playstyle and gameplay choices and preferences even when buying reactively. DotA just straight up gives you the tools to patch your weaknesses and deal with anything that could become problematic. The only league item that seems DotA like in style and in use is Hourglass. 

the former lacks most if not all strategy to make room for Action and the latter lacks Action in almost all forms to make room for strategy

**Basically, the game is decided by your actions not the actions of your opponent in a game like League. In a game like Dota the game is decided by the actions of your opponent almost always from what I can tell. I just wish there was a game that was a happy medium of these 2 concepts instead of being so dichotomous. **

Knowing how to use something rather than when to use it and what it does

When do I use the instant Veigar stun cage and where do I have to be to not be in range of it vs removing the ability to use it instantly forcing the Veigar player to do more to make up for it in terms of gameplay and interaction

Compare someone like Chogath to Reksai. The former has a set combo with little to no variation and either your opponent dodges it and you are useless or they don't and you destroy them. Reksai is a lot more sustained and give or take, reliably unreliable essentially, so the majority of doing well as her is in the players hands. 

**Im not claiming league has no strategy or is outright removing all strategy, but they are honing that strategy into more proactive and action focused things like the baron changes making it a drastically different buff than Roshan. Team wide pushing objective rather than a straight up power buff to one character. Same goes for the buffs and scuttle crab as a whole.**

I personally don't know how I feel about this. I dislike one dimensional gameplay like Veigar's stun cage being instant or old Sion's Q, but I also don't really know how to feel about literally everything getting massive mobility. If everyone has it I suppose its fine, if the only alternative is instant CC you have to memorize and can't dodge.

The core difference between League and DotA is reliability.  

In DotA, your buttons always work.  Even skillshots, which are quite infrequent, are pretty easy to land because turn rates and hit boxes.  DotA is about figuring out how to setup fights and sequence your buttons so that you win the fight.

In League, your buttons aren't reliable.  This makes the game more twitchy and more reliant on micro.  If DotA teamfights are choreographed, League teamfights are improvised -- everyone is reacting to whether or not each button worked.  Like jazz versus classical, or football versus basketball.

> Basically, the game is decided by your actions not the actions of your opponent in a game like League. In a game like Dota the game is decided by the actions of your opponent almost always from what I can tell.

I can't agree.  In both games, both teams have something to say about the result, just in a different way.  It's unfair on DotA to say that the opponent decides the game any more than it does in League; if you feel that way, it's probably because you made a strategic blunder.

You make really fair points, but I partly disagree mainly because we are making practically the same point.

In Action games all of your buttons are not reliable and in Strategy games the buttons are reliable, just the timing is usually more important than anything else. How you did your combo vs When you used your combo. 

When you take away reliability in buttons you take away a lot of "strategy" since its not all important anymore to use things at a specific time or position in a specific place because you won't always get the same result. You have to be more on the go with your approach. 

Often times when I play Dota or against an old league champion it feels like I didn't really have much say in what happened. It always felt like I shouldn't have been there, wrong place at the wrong time sort of thing rather than something I can directly trace back and improve from. I don't feel like I really learned how to play better, I just absorbed knowledge about what not to do. Like, it felt like learning a strict subject like Math rather than learning something like Martial Arts if that makes any sense.

It almost feels like playing old versions of Fire Emblem where you had to know exactly what to do and what to place where otherwise you got royally fucked. The newer Fire Emblems are more about HOW you approach a challenge rather than KNOWING how to approach the challenge. The latter is mostly the impression I got from Dota especially since the game is balanced by specifics. Certain things dont work against certain things because it would be broken, but they still let the thing exist in general. It would be like if League decided Deathfire Grasp can only be bought by Veigar and Mordekaiser.

> In Action games all of your buttons are not reliable and in Strategy games the buttons are reliable, just the timing is usually more important than anything else. How you did your combo vs When you used your combo. 

Seems broadly true in mobaland.  There are counterexamples.  Over in the fighting game genre, you generally have super reliable buttons.  The action of the game usually turns into playing rock paper scissors really fast.  In proper RTS, you often have unreliable buttons (e.g. Infestor goop, reaver scarab), but games still are dominated by strategic decision making rather than action in fights.

> When you take away reliability in buttons you take away a lot of "strategy" since its not all important anymore to use things at a specific time or position in a specific place because you won't always get the same result. You have to be more on the go with your approach. 

I think there is still strategy in League, but obviously not as much as there is in DotA.  Team DotA, being the elitist snobs they are, like to say that League is checkers to DotA's chess.  Anyway, the strategic level in League is about power spikes, rotations, and positioning.  In solo queue, I would say almost all of the strategic thinking is asked of the junglers, and the support picks up the leftovers.

It's certainly true that "strategy" involving landing a skillshot, like say a Blitz hook, isn't really possible to build a plan around.  It's like the war saying: no battle plan survives contact with the enemy.

> Often times when I play Dota or against an old league champion it feels like I didn't really have much say in what happened. It always felt like I shouldn't have been there, wrong place at the wrong time sort of thing rather than something I can directly trace back and improve from. Like, it felt like learning a strict subject like Math rather than learning something like Martial Arts if that makes any sense.

Right.  Not much you can actually do once the fight starts.  Usually the counterplay for dying in DotA involves going back 15 seconds and making a different decision.  Sometimes it goes back to items, or even to hero select.  Needless to say, for most people this is hella frustrating.
 
> It almost feels like playing old versions of Fire Emblem where you had to know exactly what to do and what to place where otherwise you got royally fucked. The newer Fire Emblems are more about HOW you approach a challenge rather than KNOWING how to approach the challenge. The latter is mostly the impression I got from Dota especially since the game is balanced by specifics. Certain things dont work against certain things because it would be broken, but they still let the thing exist in general. It would be like if League decided Deathfire Grasp can only be bought by Veigar and Mordekaiser.

DotA does indeed have a gigantic burden of knowledge problem.  No mechanic really does what it says on the tin anymore.  Even the exceptions have exceptions.  I'm pretty sure this is why DotA remains the Mac to League's PC.

Just because Veigar's stun was instant or old (and better) Sion's Q was targeted didn't mean they took less skill to use. Unlike mobile champions, Veigar and Sion paid hard for those advantages. Veigar has zero mobility, is squishy as hell, heavily mana constrained, basically doesn't have a W without the stun, and his damage otherwise is short ranged and single target. He has a *huge* pile of disadvantages to make up for the power of his stun. Effectively removing his stun doesn't add to his gameplay or make him more strategic, it just makes him worse. Likewise Sion was slow, had high mana costs, couldn't really stick to a target well, and didn't have a lot of burst unless he sacrificed sustained damage. New Sion is a flat out worse design with less reliability and power and is only being barely carried by the fact that his E is *way* undercosted.

Also the OP misunderstands the difference between dota and lol. The biggest difference is that in dota counterplay means more than "dodge the skillshot" and hero kits are much more focused on doing the thing they do really well but having weaknesses that are exploitable, while lol is land of the safe generalists with no weaknesses.

I also completely disagree. If anything, I'd say League pays more attention to the actions of your opponents than Dota, at least when it comes to how fights break down. On one hand, poor strategic decisions are more harshly punished in Dota than they are in League, but on the other there's a lot more room for moment-to-moment outplays in League than there is in Dota. Sure, mobility creep is still an issue in League that hasn't yet been fully addressed, but the core idea of placing the reliability of abilities on the skill of both parties (i.e. play and counterplay), rather than just one or the other, is a good one. Dota does have counterplay, but it's frequently detached from moment-to-moment gameplay and, more often than not, relies more on awareness of what's going on and who's doing what in a more general sense, than it is about actually reacting to any single ability (reaction is often not even a factor).

Call me a League fanboy, but in the end, despite the recurring statement that Dota is a more cerebral or skill-based game, I feel League of Legends is actually far subtler in many ways. Play and counterplay in League is a lot more granular, and tends to offer a wider (and more meaningful) range of options than Dota's gameplay, which too often relies on hard counters, unstoppable moves and mechanics more dependent on rote memorization than actual reaction. From the looks of it, Dota's actually moving a bit more towards League's philosophy of clearer kits and less steep abilities (at least judging by the Shifting Snows update, which is its latest major balance patch), but ultimately I feel League has set a framework that allows for both interesting strategic and mechanical play, even if the implementation still has a lot of flaws (that's applicable to Dota 2 as well, though, and to a much larger extent due to it still being in the middle of adding the champions from the original Dota, so just focusing on League's mistakes here is a case of the grass looking greener on the other side).
